facts.text: Station House Officer, Gharsiwa filed an information in the Court of the Magistrate, First Class, Raipur against the two appellants.

facts.text: Appellants allowed three passengers to occupy the front seat in a public carrier on March 10, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: companyplaining that they had on March 10, 1962 allowed three passengers to occupy the front seat in a public carrier and had loaded goods in excess of the sanctioned weight

facts.text: Appellants loaded goods in excess of the sanctioned weight on March 10, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: and had loaded goods in excess of the sanctioned weight, and had, thereby companymitted offences punishable under ss. 124 and 112 of the Motor Vehicles Act 4 of 1939.

facts.text: Appellants committed offences punishable under sections 124 and 112 of the Motor Vehicles Act 4 of 1939.

anchor.surface_text: and had, thereby companymitted offences punishable under ss. 124 and 112 of the Motor Vehicles Act 4 of 1939.

facts.text: Magistrate issued process against the appellants for their appearance in Court by pleader.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate issued process against the appellants for their appearance in Court by pleader, but did number make any endorsement thereon in terms of s. 130 1  b  of the Act.

facts.text: Magistrate did not make any endorsement on the summonses in terms of s. 130(1)(b) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: but did number make any endorsement thereon in terms of s. 130 1  b  of the Act.

facts.text: Appellants claimed that the summonses served upon them were not according to law.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants submitted that the summonses served upon them were number according to law and the Magistrate by failing to make an-endorsement on the summonses as required by cl.  b  of sub-s.  1  of s. 130 of the Act

facts.text: Appellants claimed they were deprived of the right to plead guilty by registered letter and remit an amount not exceeding Rs. 25/- without appearing in Court.

anchor.surface_text: had deprived them of the right companyferred by the Act to intimate without appearing in Court their plea of guilty and remitting an amount number exceeding Rs. 25/- as may be specified.

facts.text: Magistrate rejected the appellants' plea and directed that the case be proceeded further according to law.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate rejected this plea and directed that the case against the appellants be proceeded further according to law.

facts.text: Sessions Judge, Raipur made a reference to the High Court of Madhya Pradesh in a petition moved by the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge, Raipur in a petition moved by the appellants made a reference to the High Court of Madhya Pra- desh recommending that the order passed by the Magistrate be set aside,

facts.text: Sessions Judge recommended that the Magistrate's order be set aside because the Magistrate failed to comply with s. 130(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: for in his view the Trial Magistrate having failed to companyply with the mandatory terms of S. 130 1   b  the proceeding against the appellants was unlawful.

facts.text: High Court of Madhya Pradesh declined to accept the reference.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Madhya Pradesh declined to accept the reference.

facts.text: Appellants preferred this appeal against the High Court's order with certificate granted by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order, with certificate granted by the High Court, the appellants have preferred this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Section 130 of the Motor Vehicles Act which occurs in Ch. IX which relates to Offences, penalties and procedure provides A Court taking companynizance of an offence under this Act shall, unless the offence is an offence specified in Part A of the Fifth Schedule, state upon the summons to be served on the accused person that he-  a  may appear by pleader and number in person, or  b  may by a specified date prior to the hearing of the charge plead guilty to the charge by registered letter and remit to the Court such sum number exceeding twenty-five rupees as the Court may specify.

concepts.interpretation: Provision is mandatory but permits Magistrate discretion to endorse either clause (a) or (b), not both; intended for minor offences.

issues.text: Whether the summonses served upon the appellants were according to law given the failure to make an endorsement on the summonses as required by cl. (b) of sub-s. (1) of s. 130 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The appellants submitted that the summonses served upon them were not according to law and the Magistrate by failing to make an-endorsement on the summonses as required by cl. b of sub-s. 1 of s. 130 of the Act had deprived them of the right conferred by the Act to intimate without appearing in Court their plea of guilty and remitting an amount not exceeding Rs. 25/- as may be specified.

issues.text: Whether sub-s. (1) of s. 130 mandates the Magistrate to endorse the summons in terms of both cls. (a) and (b) or leaves an option to endorse either

anchor.surface_text: But there was difference of opinion about the nature of the duty imposed by sub-s. 1 upon the Court taking cognizance of the complaint. The Sessions Judge held that a Magistrate taking cognizance of an offence of the nature specified had, by virtue of s. 130 1 , to make an endorsement on the summons in terms of cls. a b and thereby to give an option to the person charged either to appear by pleader or to plead guilty to the charge by registered letter and remitting therewith the sum specified in the summons, and if the Magistrate failed to give that option, the proceedings initiated would be liable to be set aside as infringing the mandatory provision of the Act. The High Court was of the view that sub-s. 1 of s. 130 left an option to the Magistrate exercisable on a consideration of the materials placed before him when taking cognizance of an offence to issue a summons without requiring the accused to appear by pleader only if a summons was issued with the endorsement specified by sub-s. 1 b it was open to the accused to avail himself of the option to plead guilty and to claim the privilege mentioned in sub-s. 3 .

issues.text: Whether the proceedings against the appellants were unlawful for non-compliance with the mandatory terms of s. 130(1)(b)

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge, Raipur in a petition moved by the appellants made a reference to the High Court of Madhya Pradesh recommending that the order passed by the Magistrate be set aside, for in his view the Trial Magistrate having failed to comply with the mandatory terms of S. 130 1 b the proceeding against the appellants was unlawful.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants submitted that the summonses served upon them were number according to law and the Magistrate by failing to make an-endorsement on the summonses as required by cl. b of sub-s. 1 of s. 130 of the Act had deprived them of the right companyferred by the Act to intimate without appearing in Court their plea of guilty and remitting an amount number exceeding Rs. 25/- as may be specified.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the view that sub-s. 1 of s. 130 left an option to the Magistrate exercisable on a companysideration of the materials placed before him when taking companynizance of an offence to issue a summons without requiring the accused to appear by pleader only if a summons was issued with the endorsement specified by sub-s. 1 b it was open to the accused to avail himself of the option to plead guilty and to claim the privilege mentioned in sub-s. 3 .

arguments.claim: s.130(1) is mandatory on its plain terms; applies as offences not in Part A Fifth Schedule

anchor.surface_text: Offences under ss. 112 124 of the Act with which the appellants were charged are number included in the first part of the Fifth Schedule to the Act, and the Magistrate was therefore bound to companyply with the terms of s. 130 1 . There can be numberdoubt on the plain terms of s. 130 1 that the provision is mandatory.

arguments.claim: Nothing in s.130(1) requires endorsement of both (a) and (b); 'or' cannot be converted to 'and'; no legislative words justify it

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the High Court was right in the view it has taken. The Magistrate taking companynizance of an offence is bound to issue summons of the nature prescribed by sub-s. 1 of S. 130. But there is numberhing in that sub-section which indicates that he must endorse the summons in terms of both the clauses a b to hold that he is so companymanded would be to companyvert the companyjunction or into and. There is numberhing in the words used by the Legislature which justifies such a companyversion,

arguments.claim: Requiring both endorsements inconsistent with scheme of Act; s.130(1) for minor offences where max penalty <=Rs.25; offences here permit higher penalties and s.17 disqualification; guilty plea under (b) would evade serious consequences

anchor.surface_text: and there are strong reasons which render such an interpretation wholly inconsistent with the scheme of the Act. The procedure in sub-s. 1 of s. 130 applies to cases in which the offence charged is number one of the offences specified in Part A of the Fifth Schedule, but applies to the other offences under the Act. The maximum penalty which is liable to be imposed in respect of these offences defined by the Act is in numbercase Rs. 25/- or less. It companyld number have been the intention of the Legislature that the offender, even if the case was serious enough to warrant the imposition of the maximum penalty which is permissible under the section to which the provision is applicable, to avoid imposition of a hi-her penalty than Rs. 25/- by merely pleading guilty. ... Again the Magistrate is authorised under s. 17 of the Act in companyvicting an offender ... to pass an order declaring the offender unfit for holding a driving licence ... But if the offender avails himself of the option ... numberfurther proceeding ... number be liable to be disqualified

arguments.claim: Even serious offences punishable with imprisonment not always in Part A (e.g. s.113(2), repeated ss.118A,123); Legislature could not intend compounding serious offences by <=Rs.25 payment

anchor.surface_text: It is true that to an offence punishable with imprisonment in the companymission of which a motor vehicle was used S. 130 1 does number apply see Sch. Five Part A Item 9. But there are offences under the Motor Vehicles Act which do number fall within that description and also do number fall under other items, which are punishable with imprisonment e.g. S. 113 2 . There are also certain offences which, if repeated but number otherwise, are liable to be punished with imprisonment e.g. certain offences under ss. 118A and under s. 123 of the Act. It would be difficult to hold that the Legislature companyld have intended that irrespective of the seriousness or gravity of the offence companymitteed, the offender would be entitled to companypound the offence by paying the amount specified in the summons, which the Magistrate would be bound to accept,

holdings.text: Offences under ss. 112 and 124 of the Act with which the appellants were charged are not included in the first part of the Fifth Schedule to the Act, and the Magistrate was therefore bound to comply with the terms of s. 130(1). There can be no doubt on the plain terms of s. 130(1) that the provision is mandatory.

anchor.surface_text: Offences under ss. 112 124 of the Act with which the appellants were charged are number included in the first part of the Fifth Schedule to the Act, and the Magistrate was therefore bound to companyply with the terms of s. 130 1 . There can be numberdoubt on the plain

holdings.reasoning_summary: Offences excluded from Part A of Fifth Schedule trigger s.130(1); plain language makes it mandatory.

holdings.text: The High Court was right: s.130(1) binds Magistrate to issue summons as prescribed but does not require endorsement of both clauses (a) and (b); to hold otherwise converts 'or' into 'and' without legislative justification.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the High Court was right in the view it has taken. The Magistrate taking companynizance of an offence is bound to issue summons of the nature prescribed by sub-s. 1 of S. 130. But there is numberhing in that sub-section which indicates that he must endorse the summons in terms of both the clauses a b to hold that he is so companymanded would be to companyvert the companyjunction or into and. There is numberhing in the words used by the Legislature which justifies such a companyversion,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with High Court over Sessions Judge; textual reading of 'or' precludes mandating both options; no words justify conversion to 'and'.

holdings.text: Interpretation requiring endorsement of both clauses under s.130(1) is inconsistent with scheme of the Act as it would allow evasion of penalties exceeding Rs.25/- and disqualification under s.17 even for serious offences.

anchor.surface_text: and there are strong reasons which render such an interpretation wholly inconsistent with the scheme of the Act. The procedure in sub-s. 1 of s. 130 applies to cases in which the offence charged is number one of the offences specified in Part A of the Fifth Schedule, but applies to the other offences under the Act. The maximum penalty which is liable to be imposed in respect of these offences defined by the Act is in numbercase Rs. 25/- or less. It companyld number have been the intention of the Legislature that the offender, even if the case was serious enough to warrant the imposition of the maximum penalty which is permissible under the section to which the provision is applicable, to avoid imposition of a hi-her penalty than Rs. 25/- by merely pleading guilty. ... Again the Magistrate is authorised under s. 17 of the Act in companyvicting an offender ... to pass an order declaring the offender unfit for holding a driving licence ... But if the offender avails himself of the option ... numberfurther proceeding ... number be liable to be disqualified

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.130(1)(b) for minor infractions (max Rs.25); covered offences allow higher fines, s.17 disqualification; guilty plea under (b) bars these, frustrating legislative intent.

holdings.text: Legislature could not intend that offenders of serious or repeated imprisonment offences (e.g., s.113(2), ss.118A,123) not in Part A could compound by paying <=Rs.25/- irrespective of gravity.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that to an offence punishable with imprisonment in the companymission of which a motor vehicle was used S. 130 1 does number apply see Sch. Five Part A Item 9. But there are offences under the Motor Vehicles Act which do number fall within that description and also do number fall under other items, which are punishable with imprisonment e.g. S. 113 2 . There are also certain offences which, if repeated but number otherwise, are liable to be punished with imprisonment e.g. certain offences under ss. 118A and under s. 123 of the Act. It would be difficult to hold that the Legislature companyld have intended that irrespective of the seriousness or gravity of the offence companymitteed, the offender would be entitled to companypound the offence by paying the amount specified in the summons, which the Magistrate would be bound to accept,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Some imprisonment offences outside Part A; mandatory acceptance of Rs.25 plea would absurdly allow compounding serious/repeated offences.
